The **2018 Wimbledon Championships** was a [Grand
Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(tennis\) "Grand Slam \(tennis\)")
[tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis") tournament which took place at the [All
England Lawn Tennis and Croquet
Club](/wiki/All_England_Lawn_Tennis_and_Croquet_Club "All England Lawn Tennis
and Croquet Club") in [Wimbledon, London](/wiki/Wimbledon,_London "Wimbledon,
London"), United Kingdom. The main tournament began on Monday, 2 July 2018 and
finished on Sunday, 15 July 2018. Novak Djokovic won the [Gentleman's Singles
title](/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2018
Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles") and Angelique Kerber won the [Ladies
Singles title](/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles
"2018 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles").

The 2018 tournament was the 132nd edition of [The
Championships](/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon "The Championships,
Wimbledon"), the 125th staging of the Ladies’ Singles Championship event,[1]
the 51st in the [Open Era](/wiki/Open_Era_\(tennis\) "Open Era \(tennis\)")
and the third [Grand Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(tennis\) "Grand Slam
\(tennis\)") tournament of the year. It was played on grass courts and was
part of the [ATP World Tour](/wiki/2018_ATP_World_Tour "2018 ATP World Tour"),
the [WTA Tour](/wiki/2018_WTA_Tour "2018 WTA Tour"), the ITF Junior tour and
the NEC Tour. The tournament was organised by All England Lawn Tennis Club and
[International Tennis Federation](/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation
"International Tennis Federation").

[Roger Federer](/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer") and [Garbiñe
Muguruza](/wiki/Garbi%C3%B1e_Muguruza "Garbiñe Muguruza") were both
unsuccessful in defending their 2017 titles. Federer lost in the quarterfinals
to eventual finalist [Kevin Anderson](/wiki/Kevin_Anderson_\(tennis\) "Kevin
Anderson \(tennis\)"), while Muguruza lost in the second round to [Alison Van
Uytvanck](/wiki/Alison_Van_Uytvanck "Alison Van Uytvanck").

##
Tournament[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Wimbledon_Championships&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Tournament")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Centre_Court_roof.jpg/220px-
Centre_Court_roof.jpg)](/wiki/File:Centre_Court_roof.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Centre_Court_roof.jpg "Enlarge")

Centre Court where the Finals of Wimbledon take place

The 2018 Wimbledon Championships was the 132nd edition of the tournament and
was held at the [All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet
Club](/wiki/All_England_Lawn_Tennis_and_Croquet_Club "All England Lawn Tennis
and Croquet Club") in London.

The tournament was run by the [International Tennis
Federation](/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation "International Tennis
Federation") (ITF) and included in the [2018 ATP World
Tour](/wiki/2018_ATP_World_Tour "2018 ATP World Tour") and the [2018 WTA
Tour](/wiki/2018_WTA_Tour "2018 WTA Tour") calendars under the Grand Slam
category. The tournament consisted of men's (singles and doubles), women's
(singles and doubles), mixed doubles, boys (under 18 – singles and doubles)
and girls (under 18 – singles and doubles), which was also a part of the Grade
A category of tournaments for under 18, and singles and doubles events for
men's and women's [wheelchair tennis](/wiki/Wheelchair_tennis "Wheelchair
tennis") players as part of the UNIQLO Tour under the Grand Slam category.

The tournament was played only on grass courts; the main draw matches were
played at the [All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet
Club](/wiki/All_England_Lawn_Tennis_and_Croquet_Club "All England Lawn Tennis
and Croquet Club"), Wimbledon. Qualifying matches were played, from Monday 25
June to Thursday 28 June 2018, at the [Bank of England Sports
Ground](/wiki/Bank_of_England_Sports_Centre "Bank of England Sports Centre"),
[Roehampton](/wiki/Roehampton "Roehampton").[1] The Tennis sub-committee met
to decide [wild card](/wiki/Wild_card_\(sports\)#Professional_tennis "Wild
card \(sports\)") entries on 19 June.[1]

### Prize
money[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Wimbledon_Championships&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Prize money")]

The Wimbledon total prize money for 2018 had increased to £34,000,000, up by
7.6% on 2017. The winners of the men's and women's singles titles will earn
£2.25m.[2] Prize money for the men’s and women’s doubles and wheelchair
players were also increased for the 2018 competition.[3]

A new rule in 2018 was that any first round singles player who is unfit to
play and withdraws on-site after 12pm on Thursday before the start of the Main
Draw will now receive half of the First Round prize money, the other half to
be awarded to the replacement Lucky Loser. Any player who competes in the
First Round Main Draw singles and retires or performs below professional
standards, may now be subject to a fine of up to First Round prize money, to
deter players from appearing only to claim prize money.[1][4]

## Singles
seeds[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Wimbledon_Championships&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Singles seeds")]

### Gentlemen's
Singles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Wimbledon_Championships&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Gentlemen's Singles")]

The seeds for [men's
singles](/wiki/2018_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_Singles "2018
Wimbledon Championships – Men's Singles") are adjusted on a surface-based
system to reflect more accurately the individual player's grass court
achievement as per the following formula, which applies to the top 32 players
according to the ATP Rankings on 25 June 2018:

  * Take Entry System Position points at 25 June 2018.
  * Add 100% points earned for all grass court tournaments in the past 12 months (26 June 2017 – 24 June 2018).
  * Add 75% points earned for best grass court tournament in the 12 months before that (20 June 2016 – 25 June 2017).

**Rank** and **points before** are as of 2 July 2018.
